title: How Small Companies Can Benefit From Mobile App Development India?
content:encoded:
Never before have we seen such an overwhelming boom of small business apps than what we are observing now. As the citadel of tech-driven small businesses and startups, India has already come to the forefront in turning mobile apps into its footprints. The Mobile app development India is now primarily engaged in shaping the mobile presence for small businesses and startups. When focusing on the Indian market, even the global tech giants prioritize the wants and preferences of small and medium enterprises across theÂ niches.

As per the statistics published by AppAnnie, as of 2019, India stood globally in the 4th position among the countries with the highest concentration of Android users. There can hardly be any doubt that a considerable portion of these Android users and apps belong to small business apps. Other statistics confirm this. According to Cisco, 30% of the business it gets in India comes from SMEs. Big brands like Google, Microsoft and Amazon continue to focus on the Indian small enterprise market with unperturbed zeal. According to the latest data, more than 26 million small businesses in India have shaped their online presence by using various Google apps, including Gmail, Google Maps, Google Drive,Â etc.

What makes small enterprises in India consider mobile apps so crucial for their businesses? Well, the reasons are too many. Mobile apps, apart from allowing exceptional ease of operation, can help a business do growth hacking. From robust mobile branding to delivering customer service, mobile apps play a crucial role for small businesses in someÂ ways.

Let us have a quick look at some of the key ways mobile apps can benefit small businesses.

Personalized Marketing

The vast majority of customers, around 70% of them, consider personalized user experience a key factor in engaging with brands. Smartphones are quintessentially personal devices, and hence mobile apps can play a significant role in personalizing customer communication to a greatÂ extent.

By utilizing a mobile app, even small enterprises across the niches enjoy the opportunity to drive customer engagement and create strong bonds. The Indian small business sector is more evident as mobile apps are helping the so-called brick-and-mortar stores compete with big brands with a personalized experience.

Small business mobile app development India focuses on certain features, and user experience attributes push this personalization drive. For example, the use of personalized push notifications helps small enterprises connect customers easily with the right message and at the rightÂ time.

The personalized user experience can be augmented by utilizing the usersâ€™ data and location data to unleash mobile promotions, roll out new features, and create a better user experience.

Lead generation and Business Conversion

Lead generation and steady business conversion happen to be the two most important benefits of mobile apps for small businesses. Many small businesses that have limited scope in interacting directly with customers find mobile apps and social media channels as an effective medium to generate businessÂ leads.

Hyperlocal and highly context-aware marketing of services and products through mobile apps can easily push lead generation and increase business conversion. In addition, thanks to the powerful location-sensing technologies used by todayâ€™s mobile apps and because of the scope of using data-driven insights, mobile apps can play a great role in engaging customers based on their location and the specific userÂ context.

A retail business now can easily facilitate omnichannel targeting of customers with the mobile apps playing the central role in coordinating with different channels. For instance, a mobile app for a retail brand can sync the customer experience and buying process between the online store and the physical store. You scan a product while window shopping, get informed about the product through the mobile app and make the purchase order fromÂ mobile.

Helping with Operational Ease and Cost-Saving

Mobile apps can get things done in a whizz when communicating with customers, solving their issues and providing customers what they want. Operational efficiency is a key reason for many small businesses to embrace mobileÂ apps.

Companies relying heavily on the field staff can benefit tremendously from mobile apps. From monitoring the field staff in real-time to collaborating on service-related issues, mobile apps in more than one way can ensure operational ease in companies depending on field service or field professionals.

Thanks to real-time collaboration and the capability to track employees and tasks through mobile apps, businesses can also make considerable cost savings for operational tasks. Real-time information tracking and smooth collaboration powered by cloud apps ensure saving time and resources for anyÂ company.

Taking on the Opportunities of On-demand MobileÂ Apps

With the overwhelming success of Uber as the on-demand cab service app, the business model has given birth to too many on-demand apps catering to different service requirements across all niches. So today, you have doorstep food delivery apps, an on-demand app for barbers and beauticians, apps for housemaid services and apps for almost everything that can cater to on-demand needs.

The best thing about on-demand apps is that you donâ€™t need to start a completely new business catering to the demands of the customers registered through a mobile app. You can either just turn your good old website or the existing mobile app into an on-demand app to cater to more customers, or you can just register with an aggregator or marketplace app and allow customers to buy your services or products through thatÂ app.

When it comes to in-demand apps, the skyâ€™s the limit for a small business to prosper. For example, suppose you are a local grocery shop with a limited clientele. In that case, you can just build your grocery delivery app and offer doorstep delivery services throughout the whole city and even beyond the cityÂ limits.

On-demand app development in India is on the rise, thanks to the overwhelming number of unique services and solutions these apps are providing. For example, an app offering tattoo and body graffiti artists services in every city area can just be availed by the people and artist professionals alike.

Enhancing CustomerÂ Loyalty

A mobile app, unlike a website, doesnâ€™t get lost in the clamour and noise of the web. It stands out as a digital interface right on the mobile screen and keeps the brand visible all the time for the users. A customer accessing your brand through the website may not return again or quite often. But a customer using your app knows your brand more personal and is likely to interact with your brand quiteÂ often.

The mobile app can help retain users with more certainty than any other digital interface. The personalized push notifications, customer-centric value creation through loyalty programs and special offers can help boost customer footfall and brand loyalty. Mobile apps can be the right tool in the measures for customer loyalty enhancement.

Data-driven DecisionÂ Making

These days even small businesses understand the value of data and data-driven insights in the decision-making and strategy-building processes. This is where mobile apps play a very crucial role. Mobile apps help a business capture various customer data referring to locations, preferences, online user behavior, taste and choices and other factors. This huge pool of customer data can help a business make decisions affecting sales and business conversion positively.

From capturing the customerâ€™s demographic data to knowing the exact location of the customers to understanding the actual context and situation of the customers, mobile apps can help a business with potential data inputs in numerous ways. For example, depending upon the time, season, urgency and other data, a customer can be approached at the right time that boosts the chances of more purchases.

Conclusion

Did we mention all the benefits that mobile apps offer to small businesses? Unfortunately, we likely missed quite a few. But these advantages at least portray how small companies and startups can take advantage of a level playing field shared by big brands of theirÂ niches.

How Small Companies Can Benefit From Mobile App Development India? was originally published in Product Coalition on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

title: Three Types of Customers that Use Your Software Product
content:encoded:
While there are many different customer types, they are essentially in three categories.

Great digital products are not built in a vacuum. We want to build software customers love, and that sometimes requires connecting with what real people care about, and understanding from their perspective what problems are worthÂ solving.

How do we connect with these customers in order to understand them? This is where identifying customer types can be useful in focusing research activities. Here is one way you can identify three customerÂ types.

There are essentially three types of customers that use your software:

Cold Customers

They historically have not expressed a deep interest in using the product, and if they do, they rarely useÂ it.

Casual Customers

They use it more than cold customers, but they are not â€œin love with the productâ€ so it is not a habit or part of their lifestyle for them to useÂ it.

Core Customers

The customers who found a way to connect with the product. They personally discovered how it could improve their lives, they love your product, and they do not want to visualize their lives withoutÂ it.

Focus on Your Core Customers

Itâ€™s only natural to focus on your core customers, because they have valuable experiences and stories that led them to being loyal to your product. Thatâ€™s why capturing those stories can be valuable for developing other services and launching marketing initiatives. Core customers are the ones really using your product and can provide invaluable insights.

Learn about Your Cold and Casual Customers

Regarding the cold and casual users, one can work to examine their respective user journeys and the thoughts and feelings they associate with it. To accomplish this, strive to do the following:

  1. Learn about the situation that led them to yourÂ product.
  2. Understand the actions they take in yourÂ product.
  3. Understand what they think and feel as they take those actions,Â and
  4. Donâ€™t forget to askÂ why.

Evolve Your Design Process with CustomerÂ Data

Keep in mind that your customerâ€™s perception of the product matters more than yoursâ€Šâ€”â€Šso as you dive deeper into customer data, donâ€™t forget to explore how the perceptions they share can evolve your design process. In time and with enough practice, being mindful of these three types of customers can help you gain valuable knowledge to improve conversion and retention rates, and increase your software product lifespan.

Special thanks to Angela Prentner-Smith, Katherine Pickford, Leah Lockhart, Katriona Gordon, Al Morris, and the teams at This is Milk Consultancy for their input which contributed to the development of thisÂ article.

title: Three Wide-Spread Stakeholder Failures in 6:05 Minutes
content:encoded:
There are plenty of Scrum stakeholder failures. Given that Scrum is a framework with a precise and concise yet short â€œmanual,â€ this effect should not surprise anyone. While the Scrum Guide makes numerous references to stakeholders in Scrum, stakeholders themselves are no official role (accountability), no matter their crucial contribution to a Scrum teamâ€™s overallÂ success.

Explore with me three widespread examples of how stakeholders fail their Scrum teams in three short video clips, totaling 6 minutes and 5Â seconds.

Join more than 210 peers from May 27â€“29, 2021, for the Virtual Agile Camp Berlin 2021, a live virtual Barcamp using open space technology principles and practices.

The Scrum Guide on Stakeholders

Letâ€™s refresh our memories regarding stakeholders according to the 2020 Scrum Guide. While stakeholders are not an official accountability, the Scrum Guide makes numerous references to stakeholders inÂ Scrum:

Page 4: The Scrum Team and its stakeholders are open about the work and the challenges.
Page 5: The Scrum Team is responsible for all product-related activities from stakeholder collaboration, verification, maintenance, operation, experimentation, research and development, and anything else that might be required.
Page 6: The Product Owner is one person, not a committee.
Page 6: The Product Owner may represent the needs of many stakeholders in the ProductÂ Backlog.
Page 6: Those wanting to change the Product Backlog can do so by trying to convince the ProductÂ Owner.
Page 7: The Scrum Master serves the Product Owner in several ways, including facilitating stakeholder collaboration as requested orÂ needed.
Page 7: The Scrum Master serves the organization in several ways, including helping employees and stakeholders understand and enact an empirical approach for complexÂ work.
Page 7: The Scrum Master serves the organization in several ways, including removing barriers between stakeholders and ScrumÂ Teams.
Page 8: The Scrum Team may also invite other people to attend Sprint Planning to provideÂ advice.
Page 8: [Sprint Planning: Why is this Sprint valuable?] The whole Scrum Team then collaborates to define a Sprint Goal that communicates why the Sprint is valuable to stakeholders.
Page 9: The Scrum Team presents the results of their work to key stakeholders and progress toward the Product Goal is discussed.
Page 9: During the event, the Scrum Team and stakeholders review what was accomplished in the Sprint and what has changed in their environment. Based on this information, attendees collaborate on what to doÂ next.
Page 10: The Scrum Team inspects how the last Sprint went with regards to individuals, interactions, processes, tools, and their Definition ofÂ Done.
Page 10: These [Artifact] commitments exist to reinforce empiricism and the Scrum values for the Scrum Team and their stakeholders.
Page 12: However, an Increment may be delivered to stakeholders prior to the end of theÂ Sprint.
Page 12: The Definition of Done creates transparency by providing everyone a shared understanding of what work was completed as part of the Increment.

Source: The Scrum Guide on stakeholders. (This aggregation is from the Scrum Guide 2020 Reordered.)

Download the â€™Scrum Anti-Patterns Guideâ€™ forÂ Free:

Three Wide-Spread Stakeholder Failures

Let me point at three Scrum stakeholder failures that have the potential to derail your organizationâ€™s attempt at achieving business agility withÂ Scrum:

Turning the Sprint Review into a Stakeholder ApprovalÂ Instance

In my experience, the Sprint Review acceptance gate by stakeholders is an anti-pattern typical for organizations that are still rooted in the industrial paradigm, exercising command & control. Some of the reasons for this anti-pattern are:

  • A â€œmy budget, my featureâ€ attitude on the stakeholder side. The Scrum Team is seen as an internal agency, delivering requirements issued by the stakeholders.
  • The organization probably follows a metered funding approach, for example, providing a budget for the Scrum Teamâ€™s development effort only for a shortÂ period.
  • There is a general lack of trust in a Scrum Teamâ€™s ability to manage itself successfully.
  • Middle managers might even fear becoming obsolete after a successful agile transformation and try to stay theirÂ ground.

Generally, this example among stakeholder failures is a sign for an agile transformation that is not fully supported by all stakeholders.

Coders Code; They Donâ€™t Talk to Customers

Adhering to the inherited functional silos, Developers are supposed to deliver â€œcodeâ€ and only code. They are not supposed to talk to customers or take over customer support duties to understand their problems first-hand.

From my perspective, that is pure Taylorism at work, entirely output-oriented. The problem is, we are no longer assembling Model-Ts. But we go every day, where no one has ever gone before. In a complex environment, those closest to a problem are best suited to make the right decision to solveÂ it.

Hence, it becomes necessary that all Scrum team members talk directly with customers to understand their challenges better and avoid the misallocation of the Scrum teamâ€™s development time. (My rule of thumb: Coding is no more than 50 % of the whole effort of creating value for our customers. The best way to increase the productivity of a Scrum team is to avoid building unnecessary stuff. Now, guess how you can best address this issue? Right: Developers talk to customers.)

There Is no FailureÂ Culture

A former client of mine, a large utility company, practiced at the time a no-failure approach to promotions: A failed project on your internal record meant you would not take the next step on the career ladder. As a result, everyone played safe, which resulted in short-term orientation as not-failing became more important than innovation. Consequently, the organization was increasingly struggling to attract new (tech) talent when software started eating theÂ world.

Suppose â€œgoodâ€ failure is not celebrated as a critical part of the learning process, and incrementalism becomes the name of the game. In that case, the Innovatorâ€™s Dilemma, as coined by Clayton Christensen, becomes a more likely fate of the organization. When resilience is a worthwhile goal to achieve, think of Netflixâ€™s chaos monkey, failure needs to be anÂ option.

And failure needs to be openly discussedâ€Šâ€”â€Šwithout repercussionsâ€Šâ€”â€Šso everyone can learn from the case. And as it should be, leaders need to confess first. One approach could â€œfailure nights,â€ or sharing your wrong decisions from the past openly. For example, see Bessemer Venture Partnersâ€™ â€œThe Anti-Portfolio. Honoring the companies weÂ missed.â€

The Conclusion: Three Wide-Spread Stakeholder Failures

While the Scrum Guide is not honoring the crucial contribution of stakeholders for the Scrum teamâ€™s success formally, it does acknowledge their importance on numerous occasions. Interestingly, despite the severe consequences of stakeholders failing their Scrum teams, stakeholders are often not a prime focus of Scrum Masters. (Probably, because the organization is reserving the job to â€œagile coaches?â€ That would be just another anti-patterns at the organizational level.)

As a result of this neglect, these stakeholder failures may create teams of mercenaries that trade time to collect a paycheque at the end of the month, which paves the path to mediocrity, not to business agility. (After all, Scrum is a team sport, and no one is benching.)

What Scrum stakeholder anti-patterns have you observed? Please share them with us in the comments.

A â€œmy budget, my featureâ€ attitude on the stakeholder side. The Scrum Team is seen as an internal agency, delivering requirements issued by the stakeholders.
The organization probably follows a metered funding approach, for example, providing a budget for the Scrum Teamâ€™s development effort only for a shortÂ period.
There is a general lack of trust in a Scrum Teamâ€™s ability to manage itself successfully.
Middle managers might even fear becoming obsolete after a successful agile transformation and try to stay theirÂ ground.

Generally, this example among stakeholder failures is a sign for an agile transformation that is not fully supported by all stakeholders.
https://medium.com/media/f67160df06e848ae147a5071256b09e6/href
Coders Code; They Donâ€™t Talk to Customers
Adhering to the inherited functional silos, Developers are supposed to deliver â€œcodeâ€ and only code. They are not supposed to talk to customers or take over customer support duties to understand their problems first-hand.
From my perspective, that is pure Taylorism at work, entirely output-oriented. The problem is, we are no longer assembling Model-Ts. But we go every day, where no one has ever gone before. In a complex environment, those closest to a problem are best suited to make the right decision to solveÂ it.
Hence, it becomes necessary that all Scrum team members talk directly with customers to understand their challenges better and avoid the misallocation of the Scrum teamâ€™s development time. (My rule of thumb: Coding is no more than 50 % of the whole effort of creating value for our customers. The best way to increase the productivity of a Scrum team is to avoid building unnecessary stuff. Now, guess how you can best address this issue? Right: Developers talk to customers.)
https://medium.com/media/8bf7b054d7b65f097a559a52ac6e0a91/href
There Is no FailureÂ Culture
A former client of mine, a large utility company, practiced at the time a no-failure approach to promotions: A failed project on your internal record meant you would not take the next step on the career ladder. As a result, everyone played safe, which resulted in short-term orientation as not-failing became more important than innovation. Consequently, the organization was increasingly struggling to attract new (tech) talent when software started eating theÂ world.
Suppose â€œgoodâ€ failure is not celebrated as a critical part of the learning process, and incrementalism becomes the name of the game. In that case, the Innovatorâ€™s Dilemma, as coined by Clayton Christensen, becomes a more likely fate of the organization. When resilience is a worthwhile goal to achieve, think of Netflixâ€™s chaos monkey, failure needs to be anÂ option.
And failure needs to be openly discussedâ€Šâ€”â€Šwithout repercussionsâ€Šâ€”â€Šso everyone can learn from the case. And as it should be, leaders need to confess first. One approach could â€œfailure nights,â€ or sharing your wrong decisions from the past openly. For example, see Bessemer Venture Partnersâ€™ â€œThe Anti-Portfolio. Honoring the companies weÂ missed.â€
https://medium.com/media/138f4c7d25491ead7a04bce6ccdf5900/href
The Conclusion: Three Wide-Spread Stakeholder Failures
While the Scrum Guide is not honoring the crucial contribution of stakeholders for the Scrum teamâ€™s success formally, it does acknowledge their importance on numerous occasions. Interestingly, despite the severe consequences of stakeholders failing their Scrum teams, stakeholders are often not a prime focus of Scrum Masters. (Probably, because the organization is reserving the job to â€œagile coaches?â€ That would be just another anti-patterns at the organizational level.)
As a result of this neglect, these stakeholder failures may create teams of mercenaries that trade time to collect a paycheque at the end of the month, which paves the path to mediocrity, not to business agility. (After all, Scrum is a team sport, and no one is benching.)
What Scrum stakeholder anti-patterns have you observed? Please share them with us in the comments.

Finding the right software development company for a long-term partnership is usually challenging and requires a lot of research. To make things easier for you, we have compiled a list of the best app development companies with immense expertise in working with startups. The selection of companies is based on data provided by Clutch, GoodFirms, Business of Apps, and Mobile AppÂ Daily.

CitrusBits

CitrusBits is a mobile app development agency based in Los Angeles, United States. The company provides design and mobile app development services for businesses of all types. CitrusBits is a trusted partner of global brands like Burger King, Quiksilver, Symantec, and Sotheby. The agency also has huge experience in software development for startups, small and mid-sized businesses. Its key areas of mobile technology expertise cover iOS, Android, augmented reality, blockchain, and The Internet of Things (IoT). Since its inception in 2005, the company has delivered hundreds of projects and helped many businesses to build game-changing mobileÂ apps.

Since its establishment in 2014, the company has been delivering full-stack product development services for businesses globally. With 7-year-experience in serving clients remotely, Fireart has already shipped 700+ successful projects for over 200 clients around the globe. The companyâ€™s recent collaborations include Google, Rolls Royce, Atlassian, Codio, Bolt,Â etc.

The company offers a comprehensive suite of services, including UI/UX design, development, QA and testing, graphic design and branding, and explainer video creation.

Sidebench serves innovative startups and established businesses that look for product strategy, delivering them the strategic value of management consultants and experienced founders, the technical chops of expert data and systems architects, combined with the UX-first approach of one of the best product design teams in theÂ world.

Sidebench is recognized as Inc. 5000 Americaâ€™s Fastest-Growing Companies (4x-time: â€˜20/â€™19/â€™18/â€™17). It was also featured among the Best Apps & Games of 2020, W3 Awards 2020 (2x Gold Awards & 1x Silver) by the Fast Company. Entrepreneur Magazine named Sidebench one of the Most Entrepreneurial Companies in America (3x-time). Its key clients include Microsoft Corporation, Facebook, Instagram, Red Bull, Sony Pictures, Andreessen Horowitz, NBCUniversal, and manyÂ others.

Blue LabelÂ Labs

Blue Label Labs is a product development company and strategic consultancy based in New York. The agency works side-by-side with ambitious companies, brands, and founders to make bolder choices and uncover transformative change with customer-centric and truly user-validated digital products. The companyâ€™s services embrace three essential aspects: strategic business consulting, user-centric design, and impactful engineering. Blue Label Labs focuses on mobile technology development, UI/UX design, and web design. It delivers services for startups as well as for mid-sized companies and big enterprises. Blue Label Labs has created mobile applications for global brands like Bloomberg, Tide, Microsoft, Google/Alphabet, Fender, PayPal, and UnitedÂ Nations.

ChopDawg

ChopDawg is a product design and development company located in Philadelphia. The company is oriented at long-term partnerships with startups and big businesses. Since 2009, they have partnered with startups and enterprises around the world to launch 350+ next-generation apps. In recent years, Chop Dawg has partnered with major brands like Siemens, Mister Softee, Wawa, LA Gear, Six Flags Great Adventure, Choice Home Warranty, and many startups to co-create impressive digital experiences that put the end-user first and transform their business.

Key areas of their expertise include cross-Platform Apps for iOS, Android and Web, emergent technology (mixed reality, IoT, voice, wearables, artificial intelligence), product strategy and prototyping, user experience (UI/ UX), app branding, WordPress sites, mobile backend engineering, app analytics integration, and quality assurance (QA).

Conclusion

The app development industry is quickly changing, and you need to stay updated with the latest market insights to choose the right technology partner for your business. Here we have provided an overview of the five leading app development companies to make your choice more informed. Hopefully, this article will be helpful forÂ you.

title: The Hardest Thing for Product Managersâ€Šâ€”â€ŠStaying Neutral
content:encoded:
The Hardest Thing for Product Managersâ€Šâ€”â€ŠStayingÂ Neutral

Product managers can come from a lot of backgrounds, and most of them will bring a different set of valuable skills to the table. Regardless of the skills that we have, the hardest thing for me is to beÂ neutral.

What does it mean to be neutral and why is it so damnÂ hard?

We need to always go forward in the product iteration and evolve. Our mind is constantly on the hunt for that next killer feature. Most of the time we are too busy trying to find user problems and identifying user drop off that we forget one thing: does this solve anything?

We need to step back for a moment and stop thinking about what we will offer to customers. Instead, empathize about what your customers really want and desire in the firstÂ place.

Humans have the tendency to be biasedâ€Šâ€”â€Šand as we spend more time in the product, our thinkings are swayed by cognitive biases. Here are some challenges that we might find as a product manager trying to beÂ neutral:

  1. Confirmation Biasâ€Šâ€”â€ŠThe tendency to search for, interpret, focus, and remember information in a way that confirms oneâ€™s preconceptions.
  2. The Anchoring Biasâ€”The tendency to rely too heavily on the first piece of information acquired on thatÂ subject.
  3. The False-Consensus Effectâ€Šâ€”â€ŠThe tendency to overestimate how much other people agree with you. The other group that doesnâ€™t agree with you is just outliers.

Confirmation and anchoring bias is one of the most dangerous biases. Our minds will make excuses to execute a bad product or shot down a good product. The nature of human psychology is that you will mold the reality so hard until it fit the way youÂ think.

This is where exactly product managers need to be neutral. We need to have the ability to stop seeing our product as an offering or feature, but to see the product as a solution. Do we solve the problem that the customer has? Or do we solve the problem that we have in ourÂ minds?

Never ever fixated on a feature. Focus on what itÂ solves.

Of course, with that being said, there are some exercises to help reduce cognitive biases in our thinking. Here are what we canÂ do:

  • Recognize the bias: Most likely biases will influence your thinking and recognizing this is the first step to reduceÂ it.
  • Identify the bias: After we can recognize that there are some biases on our thinking, we need to be able to identify what are the biases at play. Try to step back and revisit the information that was processed. Do we process it neutrally? Or do we have preconceptions when we process the information?
  • Challenge the bias: After we can identify the bias, now we can challenge it. Try to see the problem or information from someone elseâ€™s point of view. Now try to see it under multiple scenarios. Or try to see the information as if you are seeing it for the first time with no background and see how does that change your perception.

Try to do these exercises when making decisions. Hopefully, we can all become a more neutral product manager and see things from where our users see things. Remember, the user of your product is not youâ€Šâ€”â€Šbut everyoneÂ else.

The Hardest Thing for Product Managersâ€Šâ€”â€ŠStayingÂ Neutral
Photo by Jon Flobrant onÂ Unsplash
Product managers can come from a lot of backgrounds, and most of them will bring a different set of valuable skills to the table. Regardless of the skills that we have, the hardest thing for me is to beÂ neutral.
What does it mean to be neutral and why is it so damnÂ hard?
We need to always go forward in the product iteration and evolve. Our mind is constantly on the hunt for that next killer feature. Most of the time we are too busy trying to find user problems and identifying user drop off that we forget one thing: does this solve anything?
We need to step back for a moment and stop thinking about what we will offer to customers. Instead, empathize about what your customers really want and desire in the firstÂ place.
Humans have the tendency to be biasedâ€Šâ€”â€Šand as we spend more time in the product, our thinkings are swayed by cognitive biases. Here are some challenges that we might find as a product manager trying to beÂ neutral:

Confirmation Biasâ€Šâ€”â€ŠThe tendency to search for, interpret, focus, and remember information in a way that confirms oneâ€™s preconceptions.
The Anchoring Biasâ€”The tendency to rely too heavily on the first piece of information acquired on thatÂ subject.
The False-Consensus Effectâ€Šâ€”â€ŠThe tendency to overestimate how much other people agree with you. The other group that doesnâ€™t agree with you is just outliers.

Confirmation and anchoring bias is one of the most dangerous biases. Our minds will make excuses to execute a bad product or shot down a good product. The nature of human psychology is that you will mold the reality so hard until it fit the way youÂ think.
This is where exactly product managers need to be neutral. We need to have the ability to stop seeing our product as an offering or feature, but to see the product as a solution. Do we solve the problem that the customer has? Or do we solve the problem that we have in ourÂ minds?
Never ever fixated on a feature. Focus on what itÂ solves.
Of course, with that being said, there are some exercises to help reduce cognitive biases in our thinking. Here are what we canÂ do:

Recognize the bias: Most likely biases will influence your thinking and recognizing this is the first step to reduceÂ it.
Identify the bias: After we can recognize that there are some biases on our thinking, we need to be able to identify what are the biases at play. Try to step back and revisit the information that was processed. Do we process it neutrally? Or do we have preconceptions when we process the information?
Challenge the bias: After we can identify the bias, now we can challenge it. Try to see the problem or information from someone elseâ€™s point of view. Now try to see it under multiple scenarios. Or try to see the information as if you are seeing it for the first time with no background and see how does that change your perception.

Try to do these exercises when making decisions. Hopefully, we can all become a more neutral product manager and see things from where our users see things. Remember, the user of your product is not youâ€Šâ€”â€Šbut everyoneÂ else.
